0.text:
>> Jay Foreman: An election like 2010, fantastic!
Look how excited everybody is, look how excited

14.text:
I am. Who knew that politics could make me
feel like this? How did I, a comedian, who

19.text:
normally doesn't trust anyone wearing a suit,
suddenly get so interested in politics?

25.text:
Basically, they rang me up and said 'do you
know much about politicians?' and I said 'not

31.text:
really' and they said 'perfect, you're the
man for the job.' So I am on a mission to

35.text:
find out all about politicians. First of all,
what is a politician? And second of all, how

41.text:
do you get to be one?
This is Reading West, one of the 650 constituencies

46.text:
that make up the political map of the UK.
Each constituency is represented by one Member

50.text:
of Parliament. Thousands of people in each
constituency have registered to vote and in

55.text:
a few weeks time they will get the chance
to do just that.

58.text:
Because, fanfare please, it's a general election!
On May 6th the voters of Reading West- I got

65.text:
distracted by a bee. On May 6th the voters
of Reading West will be choosing the person

69.text:
they want to represent them in Parliament,
their MP. But that's not all they will be

73.text:
doing.
Most MPs belong to a political party, each

76.text:
with a different view on how to run the country.
In a general election it's usually the party

81.text:
with the most MPs that gets to form the next
government. So by voting, you not only choose

86.text:
your MP, you also have your say about which
party you want in power for the next few years.

92.text:
In Reading West there are six people who want
to be the next MP, each from a different political

98.text:
>> Narrator: And the candidates in alphabetical
order are: Daisy Benson from the Liberal Democrats.

108.text:
Bruce Hay from the UK Independence Party,
or UKIP for short. Naz Sarkar from the Labour

114.text:
Party. Alok Sharma from the Conservative Party,
sometimes also known as the Tories. Howard

120.text:
Thomas, from the Common Sense Party. And Adrian
Windisch, from the Green Party.

127.text:
>> Jay Foreman: It's a pretty exciting election
for Reading West, because none of these candidates

133.text:
has ever been an MP before.So if they want
to get their message across to the people

137.text:
it's going to be an uphill struggle.
But enough from me, let's hear what the candidates

144.text:
have to say for themselves. Microphone please.
Thank you.

147.text:
>> Jay Foreman: Does one vote really make
a difference?

151.text:
>> Daisy Benson: Well sadly it's not even
the case that people vote once, most people

155.text:
don't vote. So yes that's a huge issue. And
if everyone did vote, particularly young people,

159.text: their voice would be listened to.

160.text:
>> Naz Sarkar: It's important to have your
say and if you don't have your say then you

165.text:
>> Adrian Windisch: It's statistically proved
that higher percentage of older people vote,

170.text:
lower percentage of younger people vote, so
they'll go for the older votes with their

175.text:
policies. If more younger people vote they'll
go for the younger vote.

178.text:
>> Jay Foreman: Are you two going to vote
in this year's general election?

183.text:
>> Jay Foreman: Why do you think it's important
to be interested in politics?

185.text:
>> Boy: You get to make a choice about what
your country is going to be like.

188.text:
>> Boy 2: If you want to make a change and
you want what you want to happen, then you

195.text:
>> Jay Foreman: I'm back in Reading and the
long wait is finally over. Today is election

204.text:
day. Now this is a polling station. It might
look like an ordinary public library, but

209.text:
for today it's been transformed into a palace
of democracy. Almost anywhere can be a polling

214.text:
station.
Okay, not that last one. But the point is

223.text:
on the inside they all do the same thing.
This is where people come to cast their vote.

228.text:
So how does it actually work?
With just a few exceptions all you need to

232.text:
be able to vote is: number one, you need to
have celebrated your 18th birthday. Number

238.text:
two, you need to have registered to vote,
which you can do any time after you're sixteen.

245.text:
Once you have registered you will know when
an election is coming up because there will

248.text:
be nothing on the tele except election specials.
You'll also be able to tell because a few

252.text:
weeks before the election a polling card will
come through your letter box.

258.text:
The polling card tells you where your local
polling station is. This is where you go to

263.text:
on election day. Or, if you think you're going
to be on holiday when the election comes you

269.text:
can send in your vote by post.
To vote at your polling station all you have

273.text:
to do is turn up. You go inside, you give
your name and address to a member of staff,

278.text:
or if you're not the chatty type just hand
them your poll card. They check your details

282.text:
against the voting register and then give
you your ballot paper.

288.text:
The ballot paper is important, because it
has the names of all the candidates in your

292.text:
constituency and the party they belong to.
So there's no need to write it on your hand

296.text:
the night before.
The polling stations have been open from seven

302.text:
o'clock this morning and won't close until
ten o'clock at night to give everyone a chance

306.text:
to cast their vote.
It's now midnight - all the polling stations

311.text:
closed two hours ago and every ballot box
from every polling station in the constituency

315.text:
has been brought here to the gym.
The furthest I'm allowed to go is just behind

321.text:
this metal fence because I'm not one of the
official counting people, but the official

325.text:
counting people over there are doing what
this all came down to, all the weeks of campaigning

330.text:
and issues comes down basically to people
doing this 'one vote, two votes, three votes,

334.text:
four votes, five votes' all night long.
The atmosphere is really starting to get a

348.text:
little bit excited and tense around here now.
I think that means there's going to be a result

354.text:
>> Spokesman: Sharma Alok Kumar, the Conservative
Party candidate, 20,523.

360.text:
>> Jay Foreman: The results are in. The new
MP for Reading West is the Conservative Party

366.text:
candidate Mr Alok Sharma.
Just like Mr Sharma winning here, the same

370.text:
thing is happening all over the country. Votes
are being counted, results are being declared...

376.text:
>> Jay Foreman: ... and the winners and losers
are making their speeches.

381.text:
>> Caroline Lucas: Thank you so much for putting
the politics of hope above the politics of

386.text:
>> Stephen Metcalfe: They have placed incredible
trust in me.

388.text:
>> Jay Foreman: The count will take all night
and we won't know which party has won until

392.text:
tomorrow.
Everyone is going home now and I'm going to

395.text:
go home too, I haven't had sleep in thirty
two hours.

400.text:
This general election more than sixteen million
people out there somewhere had the chance

404.text:
to vote and didn't bother.
In one constituency the MP won by just forty

410.text:
two votes. So think what a difference those
sixteen million voters might have made to

415.text:
the result.
So, when the time comes for you to vote, just

419.text:
think about the difference you could make.
Right, I think that's pretty much everything

423.text:
I could possibly tell you about voting. My
work here is done. I'm going home. It's over
